summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to defense counsel in the Ghislaine Maxwell case. It explains that the FBI possesses 16 discs containing a forensic image of a computer seized from Jeffrey Epstein's Palm Beach residence in 2005, but the government lacks a lawful basis to review the contents and will not seek a warrant, rendering the discs non-discoverable in the case.

events.title: Seizure of Epstein's Computer
events.description: The Palm Beach Police Department executed a search warrant and seized a computer from Jeffrey Epstein's residence in Palm Beach, Florida.

events.title: Discovery Production of 2005 Warrant
events.description: The government produced the 2005 search warrant to Ghislaine Maxwell's defense counsel as part of discovery.

events.title: Government Letter on Non-Discoverable Discs
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office formally notified defense counsel that 16 discs containing a forensic image of Epstein's computer were not discoverable due to lack of legal authority to search them.

locations: Silvio J. Mollo Building, One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007
Jeffrey Epstein's residence in Palm Beach, Florida
keyFacts: The FBI possesses 16 discs containing a forensic image of a computer seized from Jeffrey Epstein's Palm Beach residence in 2005.

The U.S. Attorney's Office states it lacks a lawful basis to review the contents of these discs because the 2005 warrant authorized seizure but not a search of the device's contents, and no subsequent warrant was obtained.
The government explicitly states it does not intend to obtain a warrant to search the Epstein computer due to the passage of time and other factors.
Therefore, the discs are deemed non-discoverable evidence in the Ghislaine Maxwell case, and defense counsel is barred from reviewing them.
The letter notes that Epstein's estate has refused to waive attorney-client privilege for devices seized from Epstein, creating an additional barrier to review.
